titlestmt.titleproper: Library Company of Philadelphia object inventories 1878-2006
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012

did.unittitle: Library Company of Philadelphia object inventories

bioghist.p: The Library Company of Philadelphia is an independent research library concentrating on American society and culture from the 17th through 19th centuries. It was founded in 1731 by Benjamin Franklin as a subscription library supported by its shareholders, as it is to this day. Free and open to the public, the Library Company houses an extensive non-circulating collection of rare books, manuscripts, broadsides, ephemera, and works of art.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of materials related to the Library Company of Philadelphia's holdings of furniture, paintings, statues, textiles, scientific instruments and apparatus, globes, medals, coins, and ceramics. Files include correspondence relating to loans, exhibitions, and conservation; conservation estimates and reports of work completed; donor and accession information; background information on individual items, their creator, and its historical context; photos; inventory records and worksheets. The collection also includes inventories of specific types of objects, including coins, manuscripts (not a complete list), and destroyed or sold objects.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
